# Purpose and Agenda

This week, we'll add to our toolkit for visualizing spatial data with `geom_sf()`, which allows us the flexibility and power to visualize data that is stored in vector spatial format.

## What we'll do in this presentation

- New mapping packages: sf and tigris
- New mapping geom: `geom_sf()`

---

# Last week: `geom_map()`

Last week, we created maps using the maps package and `geom_map()`.

`geom_map()` can use a dataframe object to create a map:

```r
ggplot(data = world_map) +
  geom_map(map = world_map,
           aes(x = long,
               y = lat,
               map_id = region)) +
    coord_fixed(1.3)
```

---

# This week: `geom_sf()`

.panelset[

.panel[.panel-name[Vector spatial data]

You will commonly encounter map outlines in other formats.

- *Vector spatial data* is a spatial data model that represents geographic features as points, lines, and polygons.

]

.panel[.panel-name[sf package]

- The sf package uses the class of simple feature (sf) for vector spatial data in R.
- The sf package was designed to replace the sp package, which has been one of the most popular and powerful spatial packages in R for more than a decade.
- sf represents vector spatial data much like a regular R data frame, but with a special column, `geometry`, that represents the shape of each feature.
- An important benefit is its compatibility with the tidyverse packages, which include widely popular packages like ggplot2 and dplyr.

```{r}
# install.packages("sf")
library(sf)
```

]

.panel[.panel-name[`geom_sf()`]

- As of ggplot2 version 3.0, the package released support for plotting simple features objects directly with the function `geom_sf()`. 
- The underlying principles and syntax to create maps and non-spatial figures are very similar.
- We can use `geom_sf()` for sf objects.

In the example below, `la_tracts` is of class sf:

```r
ggplot(la_tracts) + 
  geom_sf() + 
  theme_void()
```

]
]

# Key Concept: Simple Feature (sf)

.panelset[

.panel[.panel-name[sf storage]

The sf package provides a simply way of storing geographic information and the attributes of the geographic units in a single dataset.

```{r}
#| echo: true
#--- a dataset that comes with the sf package ---#
nc <- st_read(system.file("shape/nc.shp", package = "sf"))
```

]

.panel[.panel-name[sf class]

Inspecting the object reveals its `sf` class:

```{r}
#| echo: true
class(nc)
```

]

.panel[.panel-name[sf geometries]

Now, let’s take a look inside of nc.

- The variable `geometry` at the end, where each row represents a single simple feature geographic unit (sfg; in this case, county).
- There are different types of sfgs (`POINT`, `LINESTRING`, `POLYGON`, `MULTIPOLYGON`, etc).
- An sf object is essentially a dataframe with geometric information stored as a variable (column).

```{r}
#| echo: true
head(nc)
```

]

.panel[.panel-name[sf geometries]

Let’s take a look inside the sfg for Ashe County using `st_geometry()`.

```{r}
#| echo: true
st_geometry(nc[1, ])[[1]][[1]]
```

]

.panel[.panel-name[sf geometries]

```{r}
#| echo: true
plot(st_geometry(nc[1, ]))
```

]
]

# Creating maps from `sf` objects using ggplot2

.panelset[

.panel[.panel-name[Plotting using `geom_sf()`]

- `geom_sf()` allows for visualizing sf objects.
- Conveniently, `geom_sf()` automatically detects the geometry type of spatial objects stored in sf and draw maps accordingly.

```{r}
#| echo: true
#| eval: false
ggplot(data = nc) +
    geom_sf()
```

]

.panel[.panel-name[Plot]

```{r}
#| echo: false
#| eval: true
ggplot(data = nc) +
    geom_sf()
```

]

.panel[.panel-name[`Specifying the aesthetics`]

```{r}
#| echo: true
#| eval: false
library(ggplot2)

ggplot(data = nc) +
    geom_sf(fill = "#0C1337",
            color = "white") +
    theme_void()
```

]

.panel[.panel-name[`Specifying the aesthetics`]

```{r}
#| echo: false
#| eval: true
library(ggplot2)

ggplot(data = nc) +
    geom_sf(fill = "#0C1337",
            color = "white") +
    theme_void()
```

]
]

## If we can't use the maps package for built-in geometries, what can we use?

---

# The tigris package

.panelset[
.panel[.panel-name[tigris]

tigris is an R package that allows users to directly download and use TIGER/Line shapefiles from the US Census Bureau using R.

TIGER stands for *Topologically Integrated Geographic Encoding and Referencing* and include three general types of data:

- Legal entities
- Statistical entities
- Geographic features

```r
install.packages("tigris")
```

]

.panel[.panel-name[Downloading data]

tigris functions return simple features objects with a default year of 2021.

- See all options: <https://github.com/walkerke/tigris>
- In some cases, this subsetting is optional; in other cases, state and/or county arguments will be required.

```{r}
#| echo: true
#| eval: false
library(tigris)

tn_districts <- school_districts("Tennessee")
```

```{r}
#| include: false
library(tigris)

tn_districts <- school_districts("Tennessee")
```

```{r}
#| echo: true
class(tn_districts)
```


]

.panel[.panel-name[tigris geometries]

```{r}
#| echo: true
tn_districts
```

]

.panel[.panel-name[Plotting geometries]

We can plot our output from tigris using ggplot2 and `geom_sf()`:

```{r}
#| echo: true
ggplot(tn_districts) + 
  geom_sf()
```

]
]

# Joining data with tigris outlines

.panelset[
.panel[.panel-name[Obtaining the data]

Let's revisit our handy educationdata package:

```{r}
#| echo: true
library(educationdata)

edu_data <- get_education_data(level = "school-districts",
    source = "ccd",
    topic = "finance",
    filters = list(year = 2018,
                   fips = 47))
```

]

.panel[.panel-name[Joining the data]

```{r}
#| echo: true
tn_data <-
    left_join(tn_districts, edu_data, join_by(GEOID == leaid))

head(tn_data)
```

]

.panel[.panel-name[Plotting the data]

```{r}
#| echo: true
#| eval: false
ggplot(data = tn_data) + 
    geom_sf(aes(fill = rev_state_sch_lunch))
```

]


.panel[.panel-name[Plot]

```{r}
#| echo: false
#| eval: true
#| dpi: 300
ggplot(data = tn_data) + 
    geom_sf(aes(fill = rev_state_sch_lunch))
```

]
]

## What if I have my own map to plot?

---

.panelset[

.panel[.panel-name[Shapefiles]

- The shapefile format is a geospatial vector data format for geographic information system (GIS) software.
-  The shapefile format can spatially describe vector features: points, lines, and polygons.
- The term "shapefile" is quite common, but the format consists of a collection of files with a common filename prefix, stored in the same directory.
- The three mandatory files have filename extensions .`shp`, `.shx`, and `.dbf`.
- The actual shapefile relates specifically to the .shp file, but alone is incomplete for distribution as the other supporting files are required.

]

.panel[.panel-name[Knoxville - Knox County Zoning]

Let's say we want to map the Zoning districts from Knox County (available here: <https://www.arcgis.com/home/item.html?id=481b8a768b20403998fb9b454f35d23b>).

- We download the shapefile(s) and save it in our Week 12 folder.

```{r}
#| echo: false
#| out.width: 60%
#| fig-align: center
knitr::include_graphics("~/R/f23-founds-eds/week-12/knox.png")
```

]

panel[.panel-name[Files]

We should save all the files in the folder:

```{r}
#| echo: false
#| out.width: 60%
#| fig-align: center
knitr::include_graphics("~/R/f23-founds-eds/week-12/files.png")
```

]

.panel[.panel-name[Reading the data]

Use the function `st_read()` to read the files

- `dsn`: the path to folder in which the shapefile(s) you want to import is stored.
- name of the shapefile

```{r}
knox_zones <-
    st_read(here::here("week-12", "data", "Knoxville-Knox_County_Zoning.shp"))
```

]

.panel[.panel-name[Plotting the data]

```{r}
ggplot(data = knox_zones) +
    geom_sf()
```

]
